title.narrative: Emergency Nutrition response to IDPs in Kiltu woredas of West wollega zone

description.narrative:
Following the recent border conflict between Benishangul Gumuz and Oromia region about 199,209 (111,061 male, 88,148 female and 28,579 are children under five ) people were displaced from Kamashi zone of Benishangul Gumuz region to five woredas of East Wollega and nine woredas of West Wollega zone. Some of the internally displaced people (IDPs) are reportedly living with host communities, while others are sheltered in collective sites, mainly in Gov¬ernment buildings and schools.
Although the area is not known by chronic food insecurity and Community based management of acute malnutrition (CMAM) services are institutionalized through the routine health services, access to Outpatient therapeutic Program (OTP) and Stabilization Center (SC) remains a problem especially for the internally displaced communities(IDPs). Absence of MAM service and week referral between SAM (OTP/SC) and MAM interventions, with referral and continuum of care breakdowns intensifying the malnutrition situation in the area. According to the assessment conducted by International Medical Corps on November 2018, coverage of screening and SAM treatment service provision for displaced population with Sever and moderate malnutrition is low. SAM with medical complications was treated only in one Health Center with stabilization center (SC) and the health posts are also loaded with SAM cases of IDPs. During the assessment the major gaps identified were lack of transportation to facilitate supply from the zone to respective woredas and health posts, shortage of OTP SC materials and routine drugs, support in regular screening of children and under five, capacity building of health workers for proper service provision of SAM and MAM treatment and follow up, community sensitization and active case finding. International Medical Corps planned to provide a six month support through this project focusing on health system strengthening in full CMAM implementation, screening and capacity building trainings and joint supportive supervisions. Tripartite Field Level Agreement (FLA) will be signed with WFP and ODRMC for the TSFP implementation jointly with HEWs, woreda Health and NDRMC.
